nodes.bodyText: this should support multiple entities
Also, missing new line before static statement
break should be on the next line
The changer should also support multiple entities

As per the coding conventions file, the method order should be:
(init) -> convert -> (acceptChange) -> (change) -> getReturnType -> getPropertyName

And the Changer.ChangeMode class should be imported directly.

REMOVE_ALL should either not be supported in acceptChange or have the same behaviour as REMOVE, in this case, the former is preferred.
Also, is RESET behaviour correct here? DELETE is fine like this but resetting the fall distance definitely shouldn't behave like this. I don't believe you can "reset" the fall distance at all so it should just not be supported in acceptChange.
return should be on the next line.
Missing space before starting brace
Instead of getting the fall distance on each case, just make a variable for it before the switch statement.
wouldn't reset make more sense here?

FranKusmiruk said
'Also, is RESET behaviour correct here? DELETE is fine like this but resetting the fall distance definitely shouldn't behave like this. I don't believe you can "reset" the fall distance at all so it should just not be supported in acceptChange.'
At that point DELETE doesn't make sense, either
I believe DELETE makes a bit more sense due to the fact you can use clear fallen distance of entity, but I do get the point
hmmm i didn't think about clear. i wish we could differentiate between the two. I think i would be okay with either using delete or neither, wish a slight lean toward neither
Yup, that's what I did
delta will be null if the change mode is reset or delete, so this is preventing your delete change from doing anything
falled distance isn't proper english
this would just be one of the syntax options
What do you think about the new syntax?

remove felled and it will be perfect 👍
for this specific review though, it should just be return "fallen distance" - for getPropertyName you just return a single possibility for the syntax.
Thanks, also felled is a thing according to google
yes, felled is a the past participle of fell but it is grammatically wrong in this context
missing a space after the second || - if you're using intellij and it's git integration it might be worthwhile to enable the reformat code before commit option to catch small things like this
The issue with that is that it would always format it and if it hasn't been formatted beforehand I'm told to format it in another pull request
I mean, you can avoid committing changes unrelated to the PR or do them on a separate branch if needed

In my opinion, the name here should just be "Fall Distance"
I understand fallen is grammatically correct, but it just doesn't look right.

"felled" typical refers to the past action of falling an object, ie: falling a tree (cutting it down/knocking it over)
Personally I feel like theres a few too many options here.
In my opinion it should just be "fall". The Bukkit method is getFallDistance, i really dont feel we need fell, felled, fallen.
I cant really see someone typing set {_f} to fallen distance of player
Again, this is my opinion based on cleaning this up, but its open for discussion.
same as name of this expression, this should just be "fall distance"
For the sake of the Bukkit method being getFallDistance, this should probably be ExprFallDistance, to keep up with continuity.

+
+@Name("Fallen distance")
+@Description({"The distance an entity has fallen for"})
+@Examples({"set all entities' fallen distance to 10",
+	"on damage:",
+	"\tsend \"%victim's fall distance%\" to victim"})
+@Since("INSERT VERSION")
+public class ExprFallenDistance extends SimplePropertyExpression<Entity, Number> {

nodes.bodyText: To keep continuity, the "d" should be upper cased "Fall Distance"
I know this may seem silly/picky, but again to stick with continuity with the docs, this sentence should have a period at the end.

I see this was marked as resolved, and I was requested for review, yet nothing changed here.
If you are going to mark something as resolved, with no change, please detail why you chose to resolve it.
Class should be ExprFallDistance with the file being ExprFallDistance.java

nodes.bodyText: What happens if x is passed onto entity.setFallDistance(x) where x is negative? E.g. when the user gives a negative number, or they try and subtract too much from the entity's original fallDistance?
Not much, bukkit handles it as if it were 0
Did you actually test this? Because sometimes Bukkit may be absolutely fine with it but then when it gets passed down the chain into NMS Minecraft starts throwing exceptions...
Yeah I tested it
Still missing a .
